Posts.Content: kelleyk wrote: Hello Everyone.  I hope you all don't mind that I hopped in here and posted a new thread as I am not a survivor.  But, my mom is.  I am moved and encouraged by so many of your posts.  My mom was diagnosed with bone, liver and possibly lung mets on Feb. 1, 2010 after her initial dx of BC fifteen years ago.  We were, of course, devastated but are moving into "make it through tx mode" and she is doing fairly well.  She is 61 and cruelly, her mom died of this disease at the exact same age.  My mom started chemo (Cytoxan and Taxotere) last Tuesday and her platelets dropped to 53 from 149 in seven days.  She's been incredibly weak and she is not going into this with full reserves, physically or emotionally.  I just read the thread about the billboard and I could not agree more.  Many people are telling us...your mom needs to fight.  What does it mean to "fight" an disease anyway?  She's doing the best she can with a completely sucky situation and it is gut-wrenching watching her.  Watching her now have trouble walking, eating, staying awake while talking to me and have nosebleeds.  Also watching her cry mid-sentence and watching her be in considerable emotional pain, a pain that is singular and one that only someone in her shoes can understand.  Watching her face her worst nightmare head-on and seeing the fear and pain in her eyes. So, I am here for support, encouragement and laughter (you girls are straight-shooters and I love it), information and normalcy...all of which I will take back to my mom.  She doesn't have a computer and has difficulty operating a cordless phone, quite honestly.  And that has nothing to do with cancer.  So, thank you for having me.  You all are amazing and this forum has helped me so much already.  Sincerely, KelleyK I'm 41 and had preventive bilateral mx 14 years ago b/c of family hx;  no recon. Mom has stage IV BC (LCIS) mets in liver, bones, possibly lungs (2-1-2010) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2010 09:45PM kelleyk wrote: Hi Richard.  I am so sorry to read of your mom's Stage IV.  My mother also was recently diagnosed with Stage IV (bone, liver and possibly lung mets) on Feb. 1.  She has started chemo and is also quite weak.  I do not live terribly far from my mom (about 30 minutes), but I  have two small children (1&2) and it is definitely difficult to juggle it all.  Fortunately, my stepdad is phenomenal. But, I completely understand what you mean about your mom being a different person.  My mom has been different since her original diagnosis 15 years ago and now she's different again.  Cancer changes people in my experience and I think in my situation, my mother is protecting me.  Perhaps your mother is too.  They are mothers and that's what mothers do...protect their children, no matter the age.  I think my mom sees how much I have going on with my two girls and doesn't want to burden me with some things...I am seeing distance.  Perhaps that's what your mom is doing? And I think you are right about the random prognosis.  When I got the call about my mom, I felt a pain in my chest and immediately thought:  "We don't have long with Mom."  But after reading post after post here, that's just not necessarily the case.  Many women live years and live well in Stage IV.  I hope you and your mom are ok and I'm glad you've found this site.  It's been an incredible help to me.  God bless you and your family.  Kelleyk

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 02:42PM kelleyk wrote: Elaine (also known as "Dancing Queen" this weekend), Have a wonderful time this weekend and thank you for sharing.  My mother finished her chemo just weeks before my wedding fifteen years ago and I am so very grateful we have those memories.  Her mother died before my wedding (of BC bone mets) so there were some bittersweet moments.  But aren't there always? She was rediagnosed with Stage IV recently so here we are again...wondering what we have.  But, I am trying to focus on each and every moment and savoring it.  My girls are 1 & 2 and although they are "busy bees" for my mom at this point, I am glad I see them with her and her with them.  Enjoy your daughter's wedding.  Dance your heart out and wear those pearls proudly.  I am sure they are beautiful and you will be too.  Try not to outshine the bride.  :) Kelleyk
